body_html:
@apaszke, it is notable that our layer-by-layer profiler is not aim to substitute autograd profiler, but a supplement to it. We intent to provide a tool which could benefit not only Pytorch developers, but also users (researchers/data scientist).
Autograd profiler is a fantastic tool and we believe it must have did a lot help to PyTorch development work. However some users may not care too much about low-level function performance at first place, since they're not so familiar with PyTorch source as us. layer-by-layer profiler could provide a higher level and straightforward profile of a DL model, which could help data scientists to find out which layer is the performance bottleneck. And then they can use autograd profiler to narrow down it into low-level function range. In fact, as a performance engineer, this is the actual workflow of my daily work.

body:
@apaszke, it is notable that our layer-by-layer profiler is not aim to substitute autograd profiler, but a supplement to it. We intent to provide a tool which could benefit not only Pytorch developers, but also users (researchers/data scientist).
Autograd profiler is a fantastic tool and we believe it must have did a lot help to PyTorch development work. However some users may not care too much about low-level function performance at first place, since they're not so familiar with PyTorch source as us. layer-by-layer profiler could provide a higher level and straightforward profile of a DL model, which could help data scientists to find out which layer is the performance bottleneck. And then they can use autograd profiler to narrow down it into low-level function range. In fact, as a performance engineer, this is the actual workflow of my daily work.
